Ripple effects from the conflict in Ukraine continue to threaten the food security crisis in Afghanistan. The average price of WFP’s basic food basket has been increasing since March 2022, (though with a slight dip in September). Prices of wheat flour, wheat grain and rice remain significantly higher compared to October 2021 and the two-year average.

According to the latest WFP food security monitoring surveys, around nine in ten households (89 percent) have continued to face insufficient food consumption for the past twelve months – which is even worse than at the first peak of the pandemic (75 percent). People are now spending almost all of their income on food (92 percent), and this figure has been gradually creeping higher since the start of 2022.

WFP is racing to preposition food as the harsh winter sets in. Regional export bans continue to hinder WFP’s ability to procure sufficient food commodities in a timely manner, with long lead times persisting for internationally procured commodities. Some improvements were noted in September, following the announcement by the Government of Kazakhstan to end export restrictions on wheat and wheat flour imposed since April 2022, which is expected to increase supply to the region in the coming months.

The conflict in Ukraine has also diverted attention and resources away from Afghanistan, with humanitarian operations in the country continuing to face funding shortfalls ahead of its winter lean season scale-up. WFP continues to implement several mitigation measures, including diversifying its procurement sources and supply chain corridors, increasing local procurement where feasible, and negotiating for humanitarian exemptions for its exports from Central Asian countries and beyond.

Bangladesh is facing simultaneous crises, including the global food crisis, a fragile economic recovery from COVID-19, creeping inflation, unstable exchange rates, dwindling foreign currency reserves and price spikes for fuel and fertilizer. GDP growth is projected to fall to 5.1 percent in 2022 from 8.2 percent in 2019. The average income of the poor has already fallen 23 percent below the pre-COVID levels.
WFP is monitoring markets and food security across the country, and is exploring various solutions to protect refugees’ purchasing power under the general food assistance programme in Cox’s Bazar.

In July, the Government sought a USD 4.5 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to cope with mounting economic pressure, and provided 28 stimulus packages equivalent to USD 23 billion (6.3 percent of GDP), which benefited a total of 67.4 million people and 118,000 business entities.
Bhasan Char Rapid Food Security Assessment
Results from the second round mVAM will be published in mid-November

Bhutan recorded a 6.1 percent year-on-year increase in the consumer price index (CPI) in September. Transport costs contributed to 37 percent of the overall inflations, followed by food and alcoholic beverages, which contributed to 33 percent. For every month since March 2022, the year-on-year increase in the CPI has wavered between 5.6 and 6.6 percent.

The impact on WFP operations in Bhutan are minimal so far, since there are no direct food distributions. WFP is supporting the construction and refurbishment of kitchens and storerooms for many schools, which may be impacted by fuel and steel price increases. WFP is collaborating with the Royal Government of Bhutan (RGOB) and IFAD to prepare proposals for climate resilient agriculture production and value chains for income generation. WFP is also supporting the RGOB to access climate finance resources from the Adaptation Fund Large Innovation Grant, especially to help poor farming households to benefit from micro insurance for crop loss, using index-based insurance.
FNG (2022) assessment ongoing for Bhutan. Funded by the World Bank

The COVID-19 pandemic and consumer price shocks following the global food crisis have reversed some of the food security gains made in previous years. The country is also experiencing excess rainfall which has caused flash floods and destroyed food crops in some parts of the country. Since Cambodian households on average spend around half of their income on food, rising prices for foods (especially for imports such as vegetable oil and vegetables) and inputs for food production (fuel, fertilizers) may impact on household affordability.

The latest survey data in 2022 showed a deterioration in food security and nutrition, particularly among urban populations. Rising prices may not only render nutritious foods unaffordable but also result in lower food production and availability. In September, the cost of a balanced food basket eased off after reaching record highs in the previous month. However, flash floods have caused damage to agriculture production in some parts of the country. In addition, continuously high prices for fuel and fertilizer threaten to reduce domestic food production in the medium-term as agricultural inputs become less affordable.

WFP, in partnership with the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries expanded monthly market monitoring to 58 markets to better capture the impact of the global fuel and food crisis. With prices of fuel and fertilizer set to remain high, food prices will also likely remain high in the short term. Cambodia is weathering a cost-of-living shock that is gradually eroding household purchasing power, as manifested by declining consumer demand.

The crisis will also likely impact government programmes and drive down the value of cash transfers due to inflation, especially since current cash values are determined by the previous minimum expenditure baskets (MEB). WFP is working on a new MEB and sector-specific transfer values to provide evidence to increase the cash ration to households.

The UN Country Team launched a task force to analyse the effects of the conflict in Ukraine, and secured funding from the UN SDG Fund to enhance its monitoring efforts in Cambodia.

The Government extended its nationwide COVID-19 cash transfer programme for poor and vulnerable households to the end of September 2022. Over 2.7 million people received a total of USD 684 million between June 2020 to May 2022. Meanwhile, the Government passed a decree that allows the shortening of petrol price adjustment notice period from 15 to 10 days to reflect international price volatility.

In August, DPR Korea’s local currency (won) depreciated by 38 percent against the US Dollar, and 42 percent against the Chinese Yuan compared to 2021, which will increase the country's import bills and domestic prices. Food prices continue to increase, with a 21 percent year-on-year increase recorded on rice prices. Corn prices were 52 percent higher than that in 2019, despite a slight year-on-year decrease in August. This is likely to reduce household purchasing power, particularly the ability of vulnerable households to afford a healthy diet and cover other essential needs. Fuel prices in August 2022 have tripled compared to the same time last year. The increased fuel prices are likely to impact DPRK’s economic development, agricultural production and product transportation, which may reduce people’s access to markets, especially in remote areas, and disrupt livelihoods. International borders have been closed since February 2020, resulting in the near suspension of food imports. While the full situation is not known due to the border closures, these factors are likely to have contributed to an excessive consumption of national food reserves, and exacerbated the food security situation.

WFP’s operations in DPRK are temporarily suspended and food purchases are on hold due to prolonged border closures. The last round of distributions took place in March 2021. WFP has drafted a resumption plan to ensure a smooth resumption of the operation as soon as borders reopen.

As food and fuel prices rise, WFP’s purchasing power for food commodities is significantly reduced while the cost of WFP food transportation is soaring. The global food crisis could also delay food procurement and shipment.

UN agencies, including WFP, have prepared the 2022 response plan in DPRK to ensure well-coordinated responses when DPRK’s border reopens. Food security and nutrition is one of the main priority areas. While there is a large government social protection programme – the public distribution system (PDS) – data on PDS rations has not been updated by the local authority since August 2021.

The Government has instituted several measures to safeguard against the impact of the global food crisis. For example, on 9 September, the Government announced a ban on the export of broken rice, in addition to the existing ban on export of wheat. In addition, an export duty of 20 percent has been imposed on rice in husk (paddy or rough), husked (brown rice) and semi-milled or wholly milled rice other than par-boiled rice and basmati rice by the Government. The new duty is likely to discourage buyers from making purchases from other countries.

The prices of rice, wheat, wheat flour, edible oils and pulses have increased slightly (< 5 percent) or remained stable, as per the Government’s price monitoring system which collects price data from more than 150 locations daily across the country.
WFP will continue to provide technical support to the Government to ensure that the programmes under the National Food Security Act are efficient and effective.

On 21 September, the Government released the first advance estimate of production of crops for the 2022-23 Kharif harvest season.  As per the First Advance Estimates, the production of kharif rice is estimated at 104.9 million mt. This is 4.4 million mt higher than the five-year average (100.6 million tonnes). However, it is 6 percent lower than the production of 111.8 million mt during the last season.  As of end-October, the Government had procured nearly 11 million mt of rice against its targeted 52 million mt for distributions under government safety nets.

Amidst the current global disruptions fuelled by the ripple effects of the war in Ukraine, Indonesia has managed to maintain steady economic growth, indicating at least a partial recovery from COVID-19. In the second quarter of 2022, GDP grew by 5.4 percent on a yearly basis and was 5.0 percent higher than the previous quarter. However, a seven-year record-high annual inflation rate of 6.0 percent was recorded in September 2022, up from 4.7 percent in August. This was mainly driven by the fuel price hike after the Government increased the price of subsidised fuel by 30 percent in early September.

Meanwhile, prices of almost all key food commodities declined in September compared to August. This helped mitigate the year-on-year inflation caused by the fuel price hike. Nonetheless, the prices of almost all food commodities have recorded significant increases compared to September 2021, putting additional pressure on households’ purchasing power.

WFP will continue to closely monitor the prices of food commodities and other agricultural inputs as well as interventions implemented by the Government in response to price shocks. WFP published an Economic and Food Price Bulletin in October, which reviewed Indonesia’s current macroeconomic landscape, including implications on the economy due to the global disruptions as well as an analysis of food prices at national and regional level. A case study was also carried out in three urban villages in Jakarta to gather indicative data on the impacts of increased food prices on poor urban families to complement secondary data analysis.

From April to September, the Government launched a series of social assistance programmes in response to price shocks. These included 1) the allocation of and ceiling price of subsidised fertilizers targeting smallholder farmers; 2) low-price packaged vegetable oil (Minyakita) and unconditional cash transfers for cooking oil targeting 20.5 million beneficiary families and 2.5 million small street vendors; and 3) unconditional cash transfers for fuel targeting 20.7 million beneficiary families.

The overall year-on-year inflation reached 15.5 percent in September – among the highest in the Eurasian Economic Union countries. WFP’s food security assessment in August 2022 found that 21 percent of households, or more than 1.3 million people, were food insecure. Around a fifth of households were not consuming an adequate diet while 8 percent had an acceptable diet but were using severe coping strategies.

In the two years preceding the current global food crisis, years of development gains had already been lost. Poverty already skyrocketed from 20 percent in 2019 to 33 percent in 2021. Extreme poverty reached 6 percent in 2021 from 0.5 percent in 2019. The Kyrgyz economy is highly dependent on remittances (primarily from the Russian Federation), which made up 31 percent of national GDP in 2020 (among the highest in the world).

WFP is conducting nationwide data collection through telephone-based surveys to monitor food insecurity and household vulnerability. This comes on top of its regular market price monitoring.

WFP and partners reviewed the Government’s capacity in social protection and stand ready to expand its beneficiary base if the food security situation worsens. WFP also provided policy and technical support to replicate the piloted Social Contract nationwide and will be supporting the Government to develop a policy framework for the national “Meken Chakyrygy” public works programme.

WFP will accelerate its efforts to strengthen the Government’s capacity, including digitalization of the social passport, improvement of data quality and analysis, and advocacy for more budget allocation to school meals and social protection programmes. WFP will also strengthen the Government’s logistics capacities through warehouse rehabilitation, establishment of grain reserves, and improving the food supply chain from neighbouring countries.

The Government introduced an anti-crisis plan of KGS 126 billion (USD 1.58 billion), which includes subsidies for agriculture credits, wheat grain and flour import tax exemptions, export bans for several food commodities, a nationwide public works programme “Meken Chakyrygy” to provide temporary employment for hundreds of thousands of people, and increase social benefits and salaries of employees such as social workers.

To stabilize domestic food prices, the Government banned the export of wheat, wheat flour, sugar, vegetable oil, eggs and feed crops between February and August. To help stabilize the market, the Government also introduced Zero VAT for the import of sugar and vegetable oil.
Food Security Implications of the Ukraine-Russia Conflict: Globally and in the Kyrgyz Republic
Second round mVAM data collection completed in October, results to be published in November

Cumulative effects from the socio-economic impacts from COVID-19 and the global food crisis have exposed Lao PDR to macroeconomic instability, heightened financial risks, and negative trends in state expenditures. As a result of increasing public debt obligations and decreasing revenue, state expenditure on social services including education, health care and social protection is down. In October 2022, headline inflation rose to 37 percent, up from 34 percent. Additionally, year-on-year food inflation reached 39 percent, up from 35.5 percent in September.

Rising fuel and food prices are undermining household purchasing power in the country, adversely affecting the quality and quantity of households’ diets. These risks are particularly heightened in urban areas where households are more dependent on markets. According to WFP’s latest mVAM surveys in September, 14 percent of households are food insecure. A quarter of households reported a reduction in their income of more than 50 percent. In addition, the decrease in income sources is associated with the use of both high food-based and livelihood-based coping strategies. Increasing prices and reduced availability of agricultural inputs, including fertilizers, pesticides and fuel have constrained farmers access to these inputs, raising concerns for 2022 rice yields and increasing risks for acute food insecurity and malnutrition.

WFP continues to support the Government in preparing for and responding to the impacts of the global food crisis. In particular, WFP is strengthening the national social protection system, focusing on vulnerable and smallholder farming households through in-kind and cash transfer programmes. WFP has scaled up monitoring efforts through monthly market price monitoring and food security assessments. WFP is providing additional assistance through national school feeding programmes (continuing from the COVID-19 crisis) and will consider its further expansion, as well as the expansion of community safety nets and the provision of livelihood grants for agriculture, in case of increased needs. WFP also has rice stocks sufficient for 25,000 people. Furthermore, WFP has updated the Minimum Expenditure Basket to better inform CBT transfer values.

The Government of Lao PDR introduced several measures to address inflation and other economic challenges – such as vowing to tackle public debt and revenue leakages, boost exports, counter corruption, and create more job opportunities. The Bank of Lao PDR is responding to the crisis by controlling the parallel markets foreign exchange transactions to mitigate the significant difference between the official exchange rate and the parallel market exchange rates.

1) mVAM data collected completed, report under finalisation.

2) Monthly seasonal monitoring and internal market price monitoring ongoing.

3) A joint WFP-FAO-IFAD assessment and one joint UN assessment is planned (led by UNICEF)

Increasing levels of conflict and displacement, rising inflation and a surge in food and fuel prices are putting more people at risk of food insecurity. Based on the latest WFP-FAO estimates, 15.2 million people are food insecure (severely and moderately), showing a deterioration in the food security situation from 2021. Food prices continued to increase in September, with the cost of a basic food basket 14 percent higher than in August and 62 percent higher than the same time last year. Commodity prices continue to be impacted by rising fuel prices, which are on average 94 percent higher compared to September last year. Rice prices are also rising due to a combination of increased production costs, depreciation of the Myanmar Kyat, rising fuel prices and associated transportation costs, declining stocks, and anticipation of smaller outputs next season due to conflict-related access issues for farmers, high input costs, and drought in some areas.

WFP continues monthly monitoring of the costs of food and fuel and works with partners to identify potential activity adaptations. Based on the regular market monitoring, WFP increased monthly transfer values for select townships in Rakhine, Shan, and Kachin states from the end of August. The increases will cost an additional USD 340,000 per month.

Myanmar is subject to increased monitoring and restrictions on financial transfers after being placed on an international blacklist by the Financial Action Taskforce. While the full operational impact is yet clear, the decision is likely to affect WFP's ability to maintain cash flows of some USD 5 million per month into the country. At a minimum, delays and further costs are expected. A more likely and significant impact is that the decision could cause downward pressure on the economy, pushing more people into poverty and hunger.

WFP Myanmar is not partnering with the de facto authorities on programming. The Myanmar Food Security Cluster, co-led by WFP, FAO and Mercy Corps, continues to monitor food security in the country. Data collection for the fourth round of the WFP/FAO food security assessment has been completed and analysis is underway. The results will inform the 2023 Humanitarian Needs Overview and the 2023 Humanitarian Response Plan.
Myanmar Data in Emergencies Monitoring Brief, round 3 (July 2022)

WFP-FAO survey data collection completed (August-September), results to be published by November

While Nepal’s direct exposure to Russia and Ukraine is limited, rising food and fuel prices, export bans, and supply chain limitations for essential food items could push food even further out of reach for the most vulnerable people.

Prices of essential commodities continued to stabilize in September. However, the cost of a food basket is still 10 percent higher in September compared to April. Moreover, regional disparities are apparent: the cost of the food basket in Karnali province is 17 percent higher than the national average in September. Overall, more traders reported that the availability of commodities was inadequate to meet the demand in September 2022.

The immediate impact on WFP operations include delays in procurement and increases in the cost of operations, constraining WFP’s ability to respond. In addition, the rising costs of fuel drive a surge in food prices, affecting vulnerable communities in hard-to-reach areas for WFP programmes such as the mother and child health and nutrition programme.

WFP will continue with regularly monthly monitoring, as well as additional rapid market monitoring to analyse key market functionality (supply, demand, availability, transport), prices and macro indicators. WFP is also conducting a study to assess the impact of the global food crisis on Nepal’s food system, food security, household level agricultural production and income, livestock production, food and essential commodity prices and market functionality.

In May, the Government announced its plans to promote domestic production and consumption, and support agriculture, forestry and mining industries by connecting them with the processing industry, and introducing a programme to increase the production of food commodities which are being imported at large-scale (the start date of these interventions are unknown). It is so far not fully clear what concrete plans or relief packages the Government and development partners are putting in place to assist the vulnerable population.
World Bank Macro Poverty Outlook for Nepal: April 2022

Inflation is high in many Pacific Island Countries and Territories (PICTs) particularly for food, transport, energy and housing. These are compounded by varying local contextual challenges (lockdowns in Kiribati and Tonga; disasters in Kiribati, Tonga and Vanuatu).

There has been a continued rise in fuel prices and the consumer price index (CPI) for all five countries (Fiji, Samoa, Tonga, Vanuatu, and Kiribati) which WFP is monitoring through mVAM. The price volatility could largely be attributed to commodity markets, policy changes or seasonal or infrequent price setting as experienced by the supply chain globally.

Fiji and Vanuatu have seen an increase in overall food insecurity (rCARI) between the fourth quarter of 2021 and the second quarter of 2022. Fiji saw the steepest increase, from 43 percent to 71 percent facing food insecurity. Meanwhile, Vanuatu, which was already facing relatively high levels of food insecurity, saw an increase from 74 percent to 81 percent. For Samoa, there has been an increase in the proportion of people facing severe food insecurity over the past quarters.

One of the Pacific countries that WFP is not monitoring through mVAM, the Solomon Islands, is of particular concern, with a high level of food insecurity, high financial vulnerability and low levels of income.

*Map only shows Fiji, but the Pacific Multi-Country Office covers more countries.

WFP does not implement direct food assistance in the Pacific. Since 2020, WFP is implementing the mVAM tool on a quarterly basis in Fiji, Samoa, Tonga, Vanuatu and Kiribati to provide timely access to information on household food security indicators as well as livelihood coping strategies. The third quarter monitoring started from mid-September and will be available shortly.

The Governments in PICTs are investing to boost economies and assist populations through stimulus packages to support businesses and transfers to the population. In countries such as Fiji and Samoa, these transfers are delivered through existing social welfare systems, designed to reach the most marginalised groups. This investment has put pressure on national budgets. In Fiji, the Government implemented legislation to waive consumer tax on 21 essential food items in late March to alleviate the impact on livelihoods.

In addition, the regional Pacific Food Security Cluster co-led by WFP is monitoring through its members the impact of the crisis in the Pacific.
Impact of the Global Food Crisis on the Pacific Island Countries and Territories
Ongoing mVAM data collection for 5 countries (Fiji, Samoa, Vanuatu, Tonga and Kiribati).

2022 is an exceptionally challenging year for Pakistan, with the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, political and socioeconomic turmoil. Regional supply chain disruptions linked to the conflict in Ukraine resulted in persistently high food and fuel prices. The global fuel shortage is posing a huge challenge to Pakistan, given its heavy reliance on fossil fuels. Meanwhile, the value of the Pakistani Rupee has plunged significantly and the headline inflation is also at its highest rate in 47 years.

This situation is exacerbated further by widespread flooding in August, affecting 33 million people in 116 districts of seven provinces. Prior to the floods, 6 million people in 28 vulnerable districts in Balochistan, KP, and Sindh were estimated to be facing acute food insecurity between July and November 2022. The total number is expected to increase to 7.2 million people from December 2022 to March 2023.

WFP plans to reach 2.7 million of 4 million people in IPC Phase 4, with relief food and nutrition assistance for three months with a focus on Balochistan and Sindh. Where possible, WFP will transition to recovery and resilience activities.

WFP continues to provide livelihoods and community stabilization assistance for highly vulnerable groups to complement government social safety net programmes. This will be delivered through cash assistance or food distributions, complemented by community-based participatory activities – particularly livelihoods and resilience-building support.

WFP continues its engagement with the National Socio-Economic Registry to incorporate the latest IPC information into targeting and programming for the Benazir Income Support Programme (BISP). This will maximize the prospects of inclusion for the most vulnerable families, thereby helping to circumvent a further deterioration in their food and nutrition security.

Soaring food prices along with supply disruptions and food shortages caused by the flooding are likely to have an adverse impact on the value of WFP cash assistance and the cost of locally procured commodities. Soaring food prices along with supply disruptions and food shortages caused by the flooding are likely to have an adverse impact on the value of WFP cash assistance and the cost of locally procured commodities.

The Government’s BISP Kafalat social safety net programme currently covers 7.3 million people with a monthly stipend of PKR 2,000 per household. The current BISP beneficiaries will receive a monthly top-up of PKR 2,000 (USD 9.7) to help alleviate the impact of the global food crisis. The Government announced a petrol and diesel subsidy of PKR 28 billion (USD 136 million) for vulnerable households. In response to the flood emergency, the Government is distributing a one-off cash payment of PKR 25,000 (USD 114) per household to flood-affected families.

The impact of the war in Ukraine continues to affect domestic inflation in the Philippines. Headline inflation reached 7.7 percent in October 2022 – the highest since October 2018. Based on WFP’s market monitoring in Typhoon Odette-affected provinces, 50 percent of the traders reported that customers continued buying fewer goods than usual and 25 percent mentioned that customers bought cheaper or less preferred goods to cope with the surge in prices of goods.

The rise in the overall cost of living translates into more poor families in the country. According to the Social Weather Stations (SWS) nationwide survey in October, 12.6 million families (49 percent) considered themselves poor - a six percent increase compared to the first quarter of 2022. About 34 percent considered themselves as food-poor and 38 percent as borderline food-poor. Notably, the self-rated food poverty threshold rose to record-high in Mindanao, from 6,000 pesos to 9,500 pesos.

To monitor the impact of the global food, energy, and financial crisis, WFP has scaled up its monitoring and analysis activities in the Philippines. With support from the Joint SDG fund, WFP, FAO, and ILO are conducting household phone surveys to support existing government monitoring and surveillance systems for agriculture, food security, and social protection. WFP is also conducting monthly market monitoring in the Typhoon Odette-affected provinces of Bohol, Dinagat Islands, Southern Leyte, and Surigao del Norte.

The Government implemented targeted subsidies for the agriculture sector by supporting lower input costs, farming innovation, extension of financial assistance, fuel subsidy, and boosting the agricultural value chain.  Moreover, subsidized transportation in the capital city, Manila is extended to support up to 50 million riders, including workers and students.
Finalization of the first round of mVAM survey results ongoing; presentation of results to the Government scheduled in the first half of November.

Sri Lanka is experiencing its worst economic crisis since independence in 1948. The consequences on food security have been pronounced and sustained across the past few months; one-third of households are food insecure (32 percent in September), according to WFP’s latest survey. These figures could still increase without immediate intervention. Multiple factors are colliding to amplify the pressure, from unfavourable harvests (the most recent rice harvest is 50 percent lower than normal) and widespread shortages of key imported commodities. Meanwhile, around seven in ten households are regularly turning to food-based coping strategies such as sacrificing meals, borrowing food, and reducing the number of meals eaten. Food prices remain high in the country and nearly 64 percent of households are consuming insufficient food and less diverse diets. Markets across the regions are also reporting volatility around prices and scarcity of essential items, as seen in the latest Market Functionality Index.

WFP is responding to this crisis by scaling up operations to reach 3.4 million additional people in 2022. As of 7 November, WFP has reached around 490,000 people with cash-based transfers, in-kind food assistance, and school feeding support since commencing distributions. This includes reaching 2,490 pregnant women with value vouchers of LKR 15,000 (USD 40) each to support their food and nutritional needs. In partnership with the Government, WFP will support 1 million children aged 5 to 10 with school meals. WFP will prioritize vulnerable schools, where the Government’s national school meals programme has been halted due to budget constraints. WFP has already supported 36,000 children through the government school meals programme. WFP will also support the resumption of Sri Lanka’s Thriposha nutrition programme that provides food fortified with vitamins and minerals to undernourished children under five and pregnant and lactating women.

The Government has requested assistance from the international community and UN agencies. In mid-2022, a Humanitarian Needs and Priorities (HNP) plan was launched; this plan is currently being updated. Meanwhile the President called for a national plan ensuring food security and nutrition and welcomed all stakeholders to work collectively with the Government’s new programme to address food shortages.

1) mVAM data collection ongoing;

2) Market Functionality Index (MFI) for September: Report has been finalized

3) Market Monitor – October is at reporting stage.

The economic downturn in Russia and impact of sanctions will significantly impact Tajikistan, given its close economic ties with Russia. The proportion of food insecure households is expected to increase to as high as 36 percent from 20 percent in 2021, should the Russian economy suffer a further contraction.

A household food security assessment was conducted in Sughd and Khatlon regions, districts of the republican subordination and Dushanbe in May. The assessment indicated that the prevalence of food insecurity is around 21 percent, while 35 percent of households reported a decline in income compared to the same period last year. Among the households reporting a decline in income, 59 percent reported that it would have a significant impact on their ability to access food.

WFP will continue issuing regular updates on Tajikistan’s market situation to be shared widely with partners and donors. Russia remains the only donor of the school feeding programme, and has not yet confirmed its contribution for 2022–2023. The current crisis may result in delayed confirmation of these contributions. WFP is conducting resource mobilization activities to diversify funding sources for the school feeding programme.

WFP has also begun a face-to-face food security assessment, and is planning an IPC exercise to better understand the food security situation.
In March, the Government of Tajikistan approved its Anti-crisis Action Plan.

The war in Ukraine has contributed to an all-time high in the food price index in Timor-Leste. The Consumer Price Inflation in Timor-Leste reached 5.7 percent in the first quarter of 2022 and is forecasted to reach 7 percent on average in 2022, driven by the prices of imported energy and food. Given that Timor-Leste is a net food importer, fuel price increases are of concern. Year-on-year gasoline and diesel prices have also increased by 55 percent.

WFP continues to support the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, and General Directorate of Statistics with price monitoring to capture the effects of the war in Ukraine on escalating commodity prices and the impact of supply chain challenges in Timor-Leste. WFP is closely monitoring prices to ensure that inflation does not disrupt family spending and the affordability of essential goods.

WFP completed its mobile data collection on household food security and essential needs analysis through its remote monitoring system (mVAM) and is planning for an acute IPC training and analysis in December with the members of the National Council for Food Security, Sovereignty and Nutrition in Timor-Leste and the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO). WFP will also support the government programme to meet emerging needs by facilitating general food distribution among pregnant and lactating women.

The Ministry of Social Solidarity and Inclusion launched a new social protection programme – Bolsa da Mãe (mother’s allowance) – in three municipalities. Eligible pregnant women, children under three years of age, and children with disabilities will receive a monthly payment ranging from USD 10 to USD 20.

The Government continues to fix electricity prices and has established fuel subsidies particularly for agricultural and fishing industries. The Government allocated USD 80 million for a new Cesta-Basica (the basic basket programme) as part of its continuous efforts under the economic recovery programme to alleviate household burdens.
